Identity.History: The walrus dwells amid the ice floes in the Arctic Ocean. Both males and females have tusks, which they use to pull themselves out of the water or to anchor themselves to an ice floe, so they can sleep while still in the water. Males also use the tusks to spar for mates. The walrus eats mostly seabed-dwelling animals, and to get them, can dive over 330 feet and stay under for over 25 minutes. Walruses live in large herds sometimes containing many thousands. Walruses range anywhere from 7.5 to 11.5 feet long and can weigh up to 37,400 pounds.
